simplesect.para: This chapter is intended to be a complete reference to using Subversion. This includes the command line client (svn) and all its commands, as well as the repository administration programs (svnadmin and svnlook) and their respective commands.

sect1.title: The Subversion Command Line Client: svn
sect1.para:
To use the command line client, you type svn, the subcommand you wish to use
Yes, yes, you don't need a subcommand to use the --version switch, but we'll get to that in just a minute. , and any switches or targets that you wish to operate on—there is no specific order that the subcommand and the switches must appear in. For example, all of the following are valid ways to use svn status:
sect1.screen: $ svn -v status $ svn status -v $ svn status -v myfile
sect1.para: You can find many more examples of how to use most client commands in , commands for managing properties in

sect2.title: Switches
sect2.para: While Subversion has different switches for its subcommands, all switches are global—that is, each switch is guaranteed to mean the same thing regardless of the subcommand you use it with. For example, --verbose (-v) always means verbose output, regardless of the subcommand you use it with.

listitem.para: Goes through all the motions of running a command, but makes no actual changes—either on disk or in the repository.
Uses the contents of the file passed as an argument to this switch for the specified subcommand.

Tells Subversion that your commit message is encoded in the charset provided. The default is your operating system's native locale, and you should specify the encoding if your commit message is in any other encoding.

Specifies an argument or arguments that Subversion should pass to GNU diff when providing differences between files. If you wish to pass multiple arguments, you must enclose all of them in quotes (for example, svn diff -x "-b -E"). In addition, Subversion will display unified differences by default, so if you want default diff output, you can pass the --normal switch to diff (e.g. svn diff -x "--normal").

Forces a particular command or operation to run. There are some operations that Subversion will prevent you from doing in normal usage, but you can pass the force switch to tell Subversion I know what I'm doing as well as the possible repercussions of doing it, so let me at 'em.. This switch is the programmatic equivalent of doing your own electrical work with the power on—if you don't know what you're doing, you're likely to get a nasty shock.
If used with one or more subcommands, shows the built-in help text for each subcommand. If used alone, it displays the general client help text.
Prints output in a format suitable for concatenation.
Indicates that you will specify a commit message on the command line, following this switch. For example:
Prevents caching of authentication information (e.g. username and password) in the Subversion administrative directories.

Prevents Subversion from printing differences for deleted files. The default behavior when you remove a file is for svn diff to print the same differences that you would see if you had left the file but removed all the content.
Shows files in the status listing that would normally be omitted since they match a pattern in the svn:ignore property. See for more information.

In the case of an authentication failure, or insufficient credentials, prevents prompting for credentials (e.g. username or password). This is useful if you're running Subversion inside of an automated script and it's more appropriate to have Subversion fail than to prompt for more information.

Stops a subcommand from recursing into subdirectories. Most subcommands recurse by default, but some subcommands—usually those that have the potential to remove or undo your local modifications—do not.
Indicates that you are providing your password for authentication on the command line—otherwise, if it is needed, Subversion will prompt you for it.
Requests that the client print only essential information while performing an operation.
Makes a subcommand recurse into subdirectories. Most subcommands recurse by default.

Indicates that you're going to supply a revision (or range of revisions) for a particular operation. You can provide revision numbers, revision keywords or dates (in curly braces), as arguments to the revision switch. If you wish to provide a range of revisions, you can provide two revisions separated by a colon. For example:
See for more information.

Operates on a revision property instead of a Subversion property specific to a file or directory. This switch requires that you also pass a revision with the --revision (-r) switch. See for more details on unversioned properties.

Causes the client to display information about which files in your working copy are out-of-date. This doesn't actually update any of your files—it just shows you which files will be updated if you run svn update .

Causes Subversion to use strict semantics. By default, the log subcommand will cross copy boundaries when generating output for a file—using this switch makes log output log messages that strictly belong to the path specified.
Tells Subversion to get the list of files that you wish to operate on from the filename you provide instead of listing all the files on the command line.
Indicates that you are providing your username for authentication on the command line—otherwise, if it is needed, Subversion will prompt you for it.

Requests that the client print out as much information as it can while running any subcommand. This may result in Subversion printing out additional fields, detailed information about every file, or additional information regarding its actions.

Prints the client version info. This information not only includes the version number of the client, but also a listing of all repository access modules that the client can use to access a Subversion repository.
Prints output in xml format.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Adds files and directories

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Adds files and directories to your working copy and schedules them for addition to the repository. They will be uploaded and added to the repository on your next commit. If you add something and change your mind before committing, you can unschedule the addition using svn revert.

refsect1.title: Alternate names
refsect1.para: None

refsect1.title: Changes
refsect1.para: Working Copy

refsect1.title: Switches
refsect1.screen: --targets FILENAME --non-recursive (-N) --quiet (-q)

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: To add a file to your working copy:
refsect1.screen: $ svn add foo.c A foo.c
refsect1.para: When adding a directory, the default behavior of svn add is to recurse:
refsect1.screen: $ svn add testdir A testdir A testdir/a A testdir/b A testdir/c A testdir/d
refsect1.para: You can add a directory without adding its contents:
refsect1.screen: $ svn add --non-recursive otherdir A otherdir

refnamediv.refpurpose: Outputs the contents of the specified files or URLs.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Outputs the contents of the specified files or URLs. For listing the contents of directories, see svn list.

refsect1.title: Alternate names
refsect1.para: None

refsect1.title: Changes
refsect1.para: Nothing

refsect1.title: Accesses Repository
refsect1.para: Yes

refsect1.title: Switches
refsect1.screen: --revision (-r) REV --username USER --password PASS

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: If you want to view readme.txt in your repository without checking it out:
refsect1.screen: $ svn cat http://svn.red-bean.com/repos/test/readme.txt This is a README file. You should read this.

tip.para: If your working copy is out of date (or you have local modifications) and you want to see the HEAD revision of a file in your working copy, svn cat will automatically fetch the HEAD revision when you give it a path:

refsect1.screen:
$ cat foo.c This file is in my local working copy and has changes that I've made.
$ svn cat foo.c Latest revision fresh from the repository!

refnamediv.refpurpose: Checks out a working copy from a repository.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Checks out a working copy from a repository. If PATH is omitted, the basename of the URL will be used as the destination. If multiple URLs are given each will be checked out into a sub-directory of PATH, with the name of the sub-directory being the basename of the URL.

refsect1.title: Alternate names
refsect1.para: co

refsect1.title: Changes
refsect1.para: Creates a working copy.

refsect1.title: Accesses Repository
refsect1.para: Yes

refsect1.title: Switches
refsect1.screen: --revision (-r) REV --quiet (-q) --non-recursive (-N) --username USER --password PASS --no-auth-cache --non-interactive

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: Check out a working copy into a directory called 'mine':
refsect1.screen: $ svn checkout file:///tmp/repos/test mine A mine/a A mine/b Checked out revision 2. $ ls mine
refsect1.para: Check out 2 different directories into two separate working copies:
refsect1.screen: $ svn checkout file:///tmp/repos/test file:///tmp/repos/quiz A test/a A test/b Checked out revision 2. A quiz/l A quiz/m Checked out revision 2. $ ls quiz test
refsect1.para: Check out 2 different directories into two separate working copies, but place both into a directory called 'working copies':
refsect1.screen: $ svn checkout file:///tmp/repos/test file:///tmp/repos/quiz working-copies A working-copies/test/a A working-copies/test/b Checked out revision 2. A working-copies/quiz/l A working-copies/quiz/m Checked out revision 2. $ ls working-copies

refnamediv.refpurpose: Recursively clean up the working copy.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Recursively clean up the working copy, removing locks resuming unfinished operations. If you ever get a working copy locked error, run this command to remove stale locks and get your working copy into a useable state again. See .

refsect1.title: Alternate names
refsect1.para: None

refsect1.title: Changes
refsect1.para: Working copy

refsect1.title: Accesses Repository
refsect1.para: No

refsect1.title: Switches:
refsect1.para: None

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: Well, there's not much to the examples here as svn cleanup generates no output. If you pass no PATH, '.' is used.
refsect1.screen:
$ svn cleanup
$ svn cleanup /path/to/working-copy

refnamediv.refpurpose: Send changes from your working copy to the repository.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Send changes from your working copy to the repository. If you do not supply a log message with your commit by using either the --file or --message switch, svn will launch your editor for you to compose a commit message. See the editor-cmd section in .

refsect1.title: Alternate names
refsect1.para: ci

refsect1.title: Changes
refsect1.para: Working copy, repository

refsect1.title: Accesses Repository
refsect1.para: Yes

refsect1.title: Switches
refsect1.screen: --message (-m) TEXT --file (-F) FILE --quiet (-q) --non-recursive (-N) --targets FILENAME --force --username USER --password PASS --no-auth-cache --non-interactive --encoding ENC

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: Commit a simple modification to a file with the commit message on the command line and an implicit target of your current directory (.):
refsect1.screen: $ svn commit -m "added howto section." Sending a Transmitting file data . Committed revision 3.
refsect1.para: Commit a modification to the file foo.c (explicitly specified on the command line) with the commit message in a file named msg:
refsect1.screen: $ svn commit -F msg foo.c Sending foo.c Transmitting file data . Committed revision 5.
refsect1.para: If you want to use a file that's under version control for your commit message with --file, you need to pass the --force switch:
refsect1.screen:
$ svn commit --file file_under_vc.txt foo.c subversion/clients/cmdline/main.c:862: (apr_err=205004) svn: The log message file is under version control svn: Log message file is a versioned file; use `--force' to override.
$ svn commit --force --file file_under_vc.txt foo.c Sending foo.c Transmitting file data . Committed revision 6.
refsect1.para: To commit a file scheduled for deletion:
refsect1.screen:
svn commit -m "removed file 'c'." Deleting c
Committed revision 7.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Copy a file or directory in a working copy or in the repository.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Copy a file in a working copy or in the repository. SRC and DST can each be either a working copy (WC) path or URL:

listitem.para: Copy and schedule an item for addition (with history).
Immediately commit a copy of WC to URL.
Check out URL into WC, and schedule it for addition.
Complete server-side copy. This is usually used to branch and tag.

refsect1.title: Alternate names
refsect1.para: cp

refsect1.title: Changes
refsect1.para: Repository, and working copy if operating on files

refsect1.title: Accesses Repository
refsect1.para: Yes

refsect1.title: Switches
refsect1.screen: --message (-m) TEXT --file (-F) FILE --revision (-r) REV --quiet (-q) --username USER --password PASS --no-auth-cache --non-interactive --encoding ENC

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: Copy an item within your working copy (just schedules the copy—nothing goes into the repository until you commit):
refsect1.screen: $ svn copy foo.txt bar.txt $ svn status A + bar.txt
refsect1.para: Copy an item in your working copy to a URL in the repository (an immediate commit, so you must supply a commit message):
refsect1.screen:
$ svn copy near.txt file:///tmp/repos/test/far-away.txt -m "Remote copy."
Committed revision 8.
refsect1.para: Copy an item from the repository to your working copy (Just schedules the copy—nothing goes into the repository until you commit):

tip.para: This is the recommended way to resurrect a dead file in your repository!

refsect1.screen: $ svn copy file:///tmp/repos/test/far-away near-here A near-here
refsect1.para: And finally, copying between two URLs:
refsect1.screen:
$ svn copy file:///tmp/repos/test/far-away file:///tmp/repos/test/over-there -m "remote copy."
Committed revision 9.

tip.para: This is the easiest way to 'tag' a revision in your repository—just svn copy that revision (usually HEAD) into your tags directory.

refsect1.screen:
$ svn copy file:///tmp/repos/test/trunk file:///tmp/repos/test/tags/0.6.32-prerelease -m "tag tree"
Committed revision 12.
refsect1.para: And don't worry if you forgot to tag—you can always specify an older revision and tag anytime:
refsect1.screen:
$ svn copy -r 11 file:///tmp/repos/test/trunk file:///tmp/repos/test/tags/0.6.32-prerelease -m "Forgot to tag at rev 11"
Committed revision 13.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Delete an item from a working copy or the repository.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Items specified on the command line are scheduled for deletion upon the next commit. Files (and directories that have not been committed) are immediately removed from the working copy. The command will not remove any unversioned or modified items; use the --force switch to override this behavior.
If run on an URL, the item is deleted from the repository via an immediate commit.

refsect1.title: Alternate names
refsect1.para: del, remove, rm

refsect1.title: Changes
refsect1.para: Working copy if operating on files, Repository if operating on URLs

refsect1.title: Accesses Repository
refsect1.para: Only if operating on URLs

refsect1.title: Switches
refsect1.screen: --force --message (-m) TEXT --file (-F) FILE --quiet (-q) --targets FILENAME --username USER --password PASS --no-auth-cache --non-interactive --encoding ENC

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: Using svn to delete a file from your working copy merely schedules it to be deleted. When you commit, the file is deleted in the repository.
refsect1.screen:
$ svn delete myfile D myfile
$ svn commit -m "Deleted file 'myfile'." Deleting myfile Transmitting file data . Committed revision 14.
refsect1.para: Deleting a URL, however, is immediate, so you have to supply a log message:
refsect1.screen:
$ svn delete -m "Deleting file 'yourfile'" file:///tmp/repos/test/yourfile
Committed revision 15.
refsect1.para: Here's an example of how to force deletion of a file that has local mods:
refsect1.screen:
$ svn delete over-there subversion/clients/cmdline/delete-cmd.c:47: (apr_err=195006) svn: Attempting restricted operation for modified resource svn: Use --force to override this restriction subversion/libsvn_client/delete.c:90: (apr_err=195006) svn: 'over-there' has local modifications
$ svn delete --force over-there D over-there

refnamediv.refpurpose: Display the differences between two paths.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Display the differences between two paths. Each TARGET can be either a working copy path or URL. If no TARGET is specified, a value of '.' is assumed.
If TARGET is a URL, then revs N and M must be given via the --revision.
If TARGET is a working copy path, then the --revision switch means:

listitem.para: The server compares TARGET@N and TARGET@M.
The client compares TARGET@N against working copy.
The client compares base and working copies of TARGET.

refsect1.para: If the alternate syntax is used, the server compares URL1 and URL2 at revisions N and M respectively. If either N or M are ommitted, a value of HEAD is assumed.

refsect1.title: Alternate names
refsect1.para: di

refsect1.title: Changes
refsect1.para: Nothing

refsect1.title: Accesses Repository
refsect1.para: For obtaining differences against anything but BASE revision in your working copy

refsect1.title: Switches
refsect1.screen: --revision (-r) REV --extensions (-x) "ARGS" --non-recursive (-N) --username USER --password PASS --no-auth-cache --non-interactive --no-diff-deleted

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: Compare BASE and your working copy (One of the most popular uses of svn diff):
refsect1.screen: $ svn diff COMMITTERS Index: COMMITTERS =================================================================== --- COMMITTERS (revision 4404) +++ COMMITTERS (working copy)
refsect1.para: See how your working copy's modifications compare against an older revision:
refsect1.screen: $ svn diff -r 3900 COMMITTERS Index: COMMITTERS =================================================================== --- COMMITTERS (revision 3900) +++ COMMITTERS (working copy)
refsect1.para: Compare revision 3000 to revision 3500 using '@' syntax:
refsect1.screen: $ svn diff http://svn.collab.net/repos/svn/trunk/COMMITTERS@3000 http://svn.collab.net/repos/svn/trunk/COMMITTERS@3500 Index: COMMITTERS =================================================================== --- COMMITTERS (revision 3000) +++ COMMITTERS (revision 3500) ...
refsect1.para: Compare revision 3000 to revision 3500 using range notation (you only pass the one URL in this case):
refsect1.screen: $ svn diff -r 3000:3500 http://svn.collab.net/repos/svn/trunk/COMMITTERS Index: COMMITTERS =================================================================== --- COMMITTERS (revision 3000) +++ COMMITTERS (revision 3500)
refsect1.para: If you have a working copy, you can obtain the differences without typing in the long URLs:
refsect1.screen: $ svn diff -r 3000:3500 COMMITTERS Index: COMMITTERS =================================================================== --- COMMITTERS (revision 3000) +++ COMMITTERS (revision 3500)
refsect1.para: Use -x to pass arguments directly to the external diff program

refnamediv.refpurpose: Exports a clean directory tree.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The first form exports a clean directory tree from the repository specified by URL, at revision REV if it is given, otherwise at HEAD, into PATH. If PATH is omitted, the last component of the URL is used for the local directory name.
The second form exports a clean directory tree from the working copy specified by PATH1 into PATH2. all local changes will be preserved, but files not under revision control will not be copied.

refsect1.title: Alternate names
refsect1.para: None

refsect1.title: Changes
refsect1.para: Local disk

refsect1.title: Accesses Repository
refsect1.para: Only if exporting from a URL

refsect1.title: Switches
refsect1.screen: --revision (-r) REV --quiet (-q) --username USER --password PASS --no-auth-cache --non-interactive

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: Export from your working copy (doesn't print every file and directory):
refsect1.screen: $ svn export a-wc my-export pantheon: /tmp>
refsect1.para: Export directly from the repository (prints every file and directory):
refsect1.screen: $ svn export file:///tmp/repos my-export A my-export/test A my-export/quiz ... Exported revision 15.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Help!

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: This is your best friend when you're using Subversion and this book isn't within reach!

refsect1.title: Changes
refsect1.para: Nothing

refsect1.title: Accesses Repository
refsect1.para: No

refsect1.title: Switches
refsect1.screen: --version --quiet (-q)

refnamediv.refpurpose: Recursively commit a copy of PATH to URL.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Recursively commit a copy of PATH to URL. If there is no third argument, copy the top-level contents of PATH into URL directly. Otherwise, create NEW_ENTRY underneath URL and begin copy there.

refsect1.title: Alternate names
refsect1.para: None

refsect1.title: Changes
refsect1.para: Repository

refsect1.title: Accesses Repository
refsect1.para: Yes

refsect1.title: Switches
refsect1.screen: --message (-m) TEXT --file (-F) FILE --quiet (-q) --non-recursive (-N) --username USER --password PASS --no-auth-cache --non-interactive --encoding ENC

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: This imports the local directory 'myproj' into the root of your repository:
refsect1.screen: $ svn import -m "New import" http://svn.red-bean.com/repos/test myproj Adding myproj/sample.txt ... Transmitting file data ......... Committed revision 16.
refsect1.para: This imports the local directory 'myproj' into 'trunk/vendors' in your repository. The directory 'trunk/vendors' must exist before you import into it—svn import will not recursively create directories for you:
refsect1.screen: $ svn import -m "New import" http://svn.red-bean.com/repos/test myproj trunk/vendors/myproj Adding myproj/sample.txt ... Transmitting file data ......... Committed revision 19.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Print information about PATHs.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Print information about paths in your working copy, including:

listitem.para: Path
Name
Url
Revision
Node Kind
Last Changed Author
Last Changed Revision
Last Changed Date
Text Last Updated
Properties Last Updated
Checksum

refsect1.title: Alternate names
refsect1.para: None

refsect1.title: Changes
refsect1.para: Nothing

refsect1.title: Accesses Repository
refsect1.para: No

refsect1.title: Switches
refsect1.screen: --targets FILENAME --recursive (-R)

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: svn info will show you all the useful information that it has for items in your working copy. It will show informtion for files:
refsect1.screen: $ svn info foo.c Path: foo.c Name: foo.c Url: http://svn.red-bean.com/repos/test/foo.c Revision: 4417 Node Kind: file Schedule: normal Last Changed Author: sally Last Changed Rev: 20 Last Changed Date: 2003-01-13 16:43:13 -0600 (Mon, 13 Jan 2003) Text Last Updated: 2003-01-16 21:18:16 -0600 (Thu, 16 Jan 2003) Properties Last Updated: 2003-01-13 21:50:19 -0600 (Mon, 13 Jan 2003) Checksum: /3L38YwzhT93BWvgpdF6Zw==
refsect1.para: It will also show information for directories:
refsect1.screen: $ svn info vendors Path: trunk Url: http://svn.red-bean.com/repos/test/vendors bRevision: 19 Node Kind: directory Schedule: normal Last Changed Author: harry Last Changed Rev: 19 Last Changed Date: 2003-01-16 23:21:19 -0600 (Thu, 16 Jan 2003)

refnamediv.refpurpose: List directory entries of a URL.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: List directory entries of a URL. If URL is a file, just file entry will be displayed. svn list does not work on paths in your working copy.

refsect1.title: Alternate names
refsect1.para: ls

refsect1.title: Changes
refsect1.para: Nothing

refsect1.title: Accesses Repository
refsect1.para: Yes

refsect1.title: Switches
refsect1.screen: --revision (-r) REV --verbose (-v) --recursive (-R) --username USER --password PASS --no-auth-cache --non-interactive

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: svn list is most useful if you want to see what files a repository has without downloading a working copy:
refsect1.screen: $ svn list http://svn.red-bean.com/repos/test/support README.txt INSTALL examples/ …
refsect1.para: Like UNIX ls, you can also pass the --verbose switch for additional information:
refsect1.screen: svn list --verbose file:///tmp/repos P 16 sally 28361 Jan 16 23:18 README.txt _ 27 sally 0 Jan 18 15:27 INSTALL _ 24 harry 0 Jan 18 11:27 examples/
refsect1.para: For further details, see .

refnamediv.refpurpose: Displays commit log messages.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: When using the log command, you can operate on either URLs or PATHs.

The default target is the path of your current directory. If no arguments are supplied, svn log shows the log messages for all files and directories inside of (and including) the current working directory of your working copy. You can refine the results by specifying one or more paths, one or more revisions, or any combination of the two.
If you specify a URL alone, then it prints log messages for everything that the URL contains. If you add paths past the URL, only messages for those paths under that URL will be printed.
With --verbose, also print all affected paths with each log message. With --quiet, svn log don't print the log message body itself (this is compatible with --verbose).
Each log message is printed just once, even if more than one of the affected paths for that revision were explicitly requested. Logs cross copy history by default; use --strict to disable this.

refsect1.title: Alternate names
refsect1.para: None

refsect1.title: Changes
refsect1.para: Nothing

refsect1.title: Accesses Repository
refsect1.para: Yes

refsect1.title: Switches
refsect1.screen: --revision (-r) REV --quiet (-q) --verbose (-v) --targets FILENAME --username USER --password PASS --no-auth-cache --non-interactive --strict --incremental --xml

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: You can see the log messages for all the paths that changed in your working copy by running svn log from the top:
Examine all log messages for a particular file in your working copy:
If you don't have a working copy handy, you can log a URL:
If you want several distinct paths underneath the same URL, you can use the [URL PATH ...]] syntax.
That is the same as explicitly placing both URLs on the command line:
refsect1.screen: $ svn log http://svn.red-bean.com/repos/test/foo.c \ http://svn.red-bean.com/repos/test/foo.c ...
refsect1.para: When you're concatenating the results of multiple calls to the log command, you may want to use the --incremental switch. svn log normally prints out a dashed line at the beginning of a log message, after each subsequent log message, and following the final log message. If you ran svn log on a range of two revisions, you would get this:
However, if you wanted to gather 2 non-sequential log messages into a file, you might do something like this:
You can avoid the clutter of the double dashed lines in your output by using the incremental switch:
The --incremental switch provides similar output control when using the --xml switch.

warning.para: If you run svn log on a specific path and provide a specific revision and get no output at all
That just means that the path was not modified in that revision. If you log from the top of the repository, or know the file that changed in that revision, you can specify it explicitly:

refnamediv.refpurpose: Apply the differences between two sources to a working copy path.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: In the first form, the source URLs are specified at revisions N and M. These are the two sources to be compared. The revisions default to HEAD if omitted.
In the second form, SOURCE can be a URL or working copy item, in which case the corresponding URL is used. This URL, at revisions N and M, defines the two sources to be compared.

WCPATH is the working copy path that will receive the changes. If WCPATH is omitted, a default value of '.' is assumed, unless the sources have identical basenames that match a file within '.': in which case, the differences will be applied to that file.

refsect1.title: Alternate names
refsect1.para: None

refsect1.title: Changes
refsect1.para: Working copy

refsect1.title: Accesses Repository
refsect1.para: Only if working with URLs

refsect1.title: Switches
refsect1.screen: --revision (-r) REV --non-recursive (-N) --quiet (-q) --force --dry-run --username USER --password PASS --no-auth-cache --non-interactive

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: Merge a branch back into the trunk (assuming that you have a working copy of the trunk):
refsect1.screen: $ svn merge http://svn.red-bean.com/repos/trunk/vendors http://svn.red-bean.com/repos/branches/vendors-with-fix U myproj/tiny.txt U myproj/thhgttg.txt U myproj/win.txt U myproj/flo.txt
refsect1.para: If you branched at revision 23, and you want to merge changes on trunk into your branch, you could do this from inside the working copy of your branch:
refsect1.screen: $ svn merge -r 23:30 file:///tmp/repos/trunk/vendors U myproj/thhgttg.txt ...
refsect1.para: To merge changes to a single file:
refsect1.screen: +$ cd myproj +$ svn merge -r 30:31 thhgttg.txt +U thhgttg.txt

refnamediv.refpurpose: Create a new directory under revision control.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Create a directory with a name given by the final component of TARGET. If TARGET is a working copy path the directory is scheduled for addition in the working copy. If TARGET is an URL the directory is created in the repository via an immediate commit. In both cases all the intermediate directories must already exist.

refsect1.title: Alternate names
refsect1.para: None

refsect1.title: Changes
refsect1.para: Working copy, repository if operating on a URL

refsect1.title: Accesses Repository
refsect1.para: Only if operating on a URL

refsect1.title: Switches
refsect1.screen: --message (-m) TEXT --file (-F) FILE --quiet (-q) --username USER --password PASS --no-auth-cache --non-interactive --encoding ENC

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: Create a directory in your working copy:
refsect1.screen: $ svn mkdir newdir A newdir
refsect1.para: Create on in the repository (instant commit, so a log message is required):
refsect1.screen:
$ svn mkdir -m "Making a new dir." http://svn.red-bean.com/repos/newdir
Committed revision 26.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Move a file or directory.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: This command moves a file or directory in your working copy or in the repository.

tip.para: This command is equivalent to a svn copy followed by svn delete.

warning.para: Subversion does not support moving between working copies and URLs.

listitem.para: Move and schedule a file or directory for addition (with history).
Complete server-side rename.

refsect1.title: Alternate names
refsect1.para: mv, rename, ren

refsect1.title: Changes
refsect1.para: Working copy, repository if operating on a URL

refsect1.title: Accesses Repository
refsect1.para: Only if operating on a URL

refsect1.title: Switches
refsect1.screen: --message (-m) TEXT --file (-F) FILE --revision (-r) REV --quiet (-q) --username USER --password PASS --no-auth-cache --non-interactive --force --encoding ENC

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: Move a file in your working copy:
refsect1.screen: $ svn move foo.c bar.c A bar.c D foo.c
refsect1.para: Move a file in the repository (an immediate commit, so it requires a commit message):
refsect1.screen:
$ svn move -m "Move a file" http://svn.red-bean.com/repos/foo.c http://svn.red-bean.com/repos/bar.c
Committed revision 27.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Set PROPNAME to PROPVAL on files, directories, or revisions.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Set PROPNAME to PROPVAL on files, directories, or revisions. The first example creates a versioned, local propchange in working copy, and the second creates an unversioned, remote propchange on a repository revision.

tip.para: Subversion has a number of special properties that affect its behavior. See for more on these properties.

refsect1.title: Alternate names
refsect1.para: pset, ps

refsect1.title: Changes
refsect1.para: Working copy, repository only if operating on a URL

refsect1.title: Accesses Repository
refsect1.para: Only if operating on a URL

refsect1.title: Switches
refsect1.screen: --file (-F) FILE --quiet (-q) --revision (-r) REV --targets FILENAME --recursive (-R) --revprop --encoding ENC

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: Set the mimetype on a file:
refsect1.screen: $ svn propset svn:mime-type image/jpeg foo.jpg property `svn:mime-type' set on 'foo.jpg'
refsect1.para: On a UNIX system, if you want a file to have the executable permission set:
refsect1.screen: $ svn propset svn:executable ON somescript property `svn:executable' set on 'somescript'
refsect1.para: Perhaps you have an internal policy to set certain properties for the benefit of your coworkers:
refsect1.screen: $ svn propset owner sally foo.c property `owner' set on 'foo.c'
refsect1.para: If you made a mistake in a log message for a particular revision and want to change it, use --revprop and set svn:log to the new log message:
refsect1.screen: $ svn propset --revprop -r 25 svn:log "Journaled about trip to New York." property `svn:log' set on repository revision '25'
refsect1.para: Or, if you don't have a working copy, you can provide a URL.
refsect1.screen: $ svn propset --revprop -r 26 svn:log "Document nap." http://svn.red-bean.com/repos property `svn:log' set on repository revision '25'
refsect1.para: Lastly, you can tell propset to take its input from a file. You could even use this to set the contents of a property to something binary:
refsect1.screen: $ svn propset owner-pic -F sally.jpg moo.c property `owner-pic' set on 'moo.c'

warning.para: By default, you cannot modify revision properties in a Subversion repository. Your repository administrator must explicitly enable revision property modifications by creating a hook named 'pre-revprop-change'. See for more information on hook scripts.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Remove a property from an item.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: This removes properties from files, directories, or revisions. The first form removes versioned properties in working copy, while the second removes unversioned remote properties on a repository revision.

refsect1.title: Alternate names
refsect1.para: pdel

refsect1.title: Changes
refsect1.para: Working copy, repository only if operating on a URL

refsect1.title: Accesses Repository
refsect1.para: Only if operating on a URL

refsect1.title: Switches
refsect1.screen: --quiet (-q) --recursive (-R) --revision (-r) REV --revprop

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: Delete a property from a file in your working copy
refsect1.screen: $ svn propdel svn:mime-type some-script property `svn:mime-type' deleted from 'some-script'.
refsect1.para: Delete a revision property:
refsect1.screen: $ svn propdel --revprop -r 26 release-date property `release-date' deleted from repository revision '26'

refnamediv.refpurpose: Edit the property of one or more items under version control.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Edits one or more properties using your favorite editor. The first form edits versioned properties in your working copy, while the second edits unversioned remote properties on a repository revision.

refsect1.title: Alternate names
refsect1.para: pedit, pe

refsect1.title: Changes
refsect1.para: Working copy, repository only if operating on a URL

refsect1.title: Accesses Repository
refsect1.para: Only if operating on a URL

refsect1.title: Switches
refsect1.screen: --revision (-r) REV --revprop --encoding ENC

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: svn propedit makes it easy to modify properties that have multiple values:
refsect1.screen: $ svn propedit svn:keywords foo.c <svn will launch your favorite editor here, with a buffer open containing the current contents of the svn:keywords property. You can add multiple values to a property easily here by entering one value per line.> Set new value for property `svn:keywords' on `foo.c'

refnamediv.refpurpose: Prints the value of a property.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Prints the value of a property on files, directories, or revisions. The first form prints the versioned property of an item or items in your working copy, while the second prints unversioned remote property on a repository revision. See for more information on properties.

refsect1.title: Alternate names
refsect1.para: pget, pg

refsect1.title: Changes
refsect1.para: Working copy, repository only if operating on a URL

refsect1.title: Accesses Repository
refsect1.para: Only if operating on a URL

refsect1.title: Switches
refsect1.screen: --recursive (-R) --revision (-r) REV --revprop

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: Examine a property of a file in your working copy:
refsect1.screen: $ svn propget svn:keywords foo.c Author Date Rev
refsect1.para: The same goes for a revision property:
refsect1.screen: $ svn propget svn:log --revprop -r 20 Began journal.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Lists all properties.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Lists all properties on files, directories, or revisions. The first form lists versioned properties in working copy, while the second lists unversioned remote properties on a repository revision.

refsect1.title: Alternate names
refsect1.para: plist, pl

refsect1.title: Changes
refsect1.para: Working copy, repository only if operating on a URL

refsect1.title: Accesses Repository
refsect1.para: Only if operating on a URL

refsect1.title: Switches
refsect1.screen: --verbose (-v) --recursive (-R) --revision (-r) REV --revprop

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: You can use proplist to see the properties on an item in your working copy:
refsect1.screen: $ svn proplist foo.c Properties on 'foo.c': svn:mime-type svn:keywords owner
refsect1.para: But with the --verbose flag, svn proplist is extremely handy as it also shows you the values for the properties:
refsect1.screen: $ svn proplist --verbose foo.c Properties on 'foo.c': svn:mime-type : text/plain svn:keywords : Author Date Rev owner : sally

refnamediv.refpurpose: Undo all local edits.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Reverts any local changes to a file or directory and resolves any conflicted states. svn revert will not only revert the contents of an item in your working copy, but also any property changes. Finally, you can use it to undo any scheduling operations that you may have done (e.g. files scheduled for addition or deletion can be unscheduled).

refsect1.title: Alternate names
refsect1.para: None

refsect1.title: Changes
refsect1.para: Working copy

refsect1.title: Accesses Repository
refsect1.para: No

refsect1.title: Switches
refsect1.screen: --targets FILENAME --recursive (-R) --quiet (-q)

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: Discard changes to a file:
refsect1.screen: $ svn revert foo.c Reverted foo.c
refsect1.para: If you want to revert a whole directory of files, use the --recursive flag:
refsect1.screen: $svn revert --recursive . Reverted newdir/afile Reverted foo.c Reverted bar.txt
refsect1.para: Lastly, you can undo any scheduling operations:
refsect1.screen:
$ svn add mistake.txt whoops A mistake.txt A whoops A whoops/oopsie.c
$ svn revert mistake.txt whoops Reverted mistake.txt Reverted whoops
$ svn status ? mistake.txt ? whoops

warning.para: If you provide no targets to svn revert, it will do nothing—to protect you from accidentally losing changes in your working copy, svn revert requires you to provide at least one target.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Remove conflicted state on working copy files or directories.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Remove conflicted state on working copy files or directories. This routine does not semantically resolve conflict markers; it merely removes conflict-related artifact files and allows PATH to be committed again. See for an in-depth look at resolving conflicts.

refsect1.title: Alternate names
refsect1.para: None

refsect1.title: Changes
refsect1.para: Working copy

refsect1.title: Accesses Repository
refsect1.para: No

refsect1.title: Switches
refsect1.screen: --targets FILENAME --recursive (-R) --quiet (-q)

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: If you get a conflict on an update, your working copy will sprout three new files:
refsect1.screen: $ svn update C foo.c Updated to revision 31. $ ls foo.c foo.c.mine foo.c.r30 foo.c.r31
refsect1.para: Once you've resolved the conflict and foo.c is ready to be committed, run svn resolve to let your working copy know you've taken care of everything.

warning.para: You can just remove the conflict files and commit, but svn resolve fixes up some bookkeeping data in the working copy administrative area in addition to removing the conflict files, so we recommend that you use this command.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Print the status of working copy files and directories.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Print the status of working copy files and directories. With no args, it prints only locally modified items (no repository access). With --show-updates, add working revision and server out-of-date information. With --verbose, print full revision information on every item.
The first five columns in the output are each one character wide, and each column gives you information about different aspects of each working copy item.
The first column indicates that an item was added, deleted, or otherwise changed.

listitem.para: No modifications.
Item is scheduled for Addition.
Item is scheduled for Addition.
Item has been modified.
Item is in conflict with updates received from the repository.
Item is not under version control.
Item is missing (e.g. you moved or deleted it without using svn).
Item is versioned as a directory, but has been replaced by a file, or vice versa

refsect1.para: The second column tells the status of a file's or directory's properties.

listitem.para: No modifications.
Properties for this item have been modified.
Properties for this item are in conflict with property updates received from the repository.

refsect1.para: The third column is populated only if the working copy directory is locked.

listitem.para: Item is not locked.
Item is locked.

refsect1.para: The fourth column is populated only if the item is scheduled for addition-with-history.

listitem.para: No history scheduled with commit.
History scheduled with commit.

refsect1.para: The fifth column is populated only if the item is switched relative to its parent (See ).

listitem.para: Item is child of its parent directory.
Item is switched.

refsect1.para: The out-of-date information appears in the eighth column (only if you pass the --show-updates switch).

listitem.para: The item in your working copy is up-to-date.
A newer revision of the item exists on the server.

refsect1.para: The remaining fields are variable width and delimited by spaces. The working revision is the next field if the --show-updates or --verboseswitches are passed.
If the --verbose switch is passed, the last committed revision and last committed author are displayed next.
The working copy path is always the final field, so it can include spaces.

refsect1.title: Alternate names
refsect1.para: stat, st

refsect1.title: Changes
refsect1.para: Nothing

refsect1.title: Accesses Repository
refsect1.para: Only if using --show-updates

refsect1.title: Switches
refsect1.screen: --show-updates (-u) --verbose (-v) --non-recursive (-N) --quiet (-q) --username USER --password PASS --no-auth-cache --non-interactive --no-ignore

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: This is the easiest way to find out what changes you have made to your working copy:
refsect1.screen: $ svn status wc M wc/bar.c A + wc/qax.c
refsect1.para: If you want to find out what files in your working copy are out-of-date, pass the --show-updates switch (This will not make any changes to your working copy). Here you can see that wc/foo.c has changed in the repository since we last updated our working copy:
refsect1.screen: $ svn status --show-updates wc M 965 wc/bar.c * 965 wc/foo.c A + 965 wc/qax.c Head revision: 981
refsect1.para: And finally, the most information you can get out of the status subcommand:
refsect1.screen: $ svn status --show-updates --verbose wc M 965 938 sally wc/bar.c * 965 922 harry wc/foo.c A + 965 687 harry wc/qax.c 965 687 harry wc/zig.c Head revision: 981
refsect1.para: For many more examples of svn status, see .

refnamediv.refpurpose: Update working copy to a different URL.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: This subcommand updates your working copy to mirror a new URL—usually a URL which shares a common ancestor with your working copy, although not necessarily. This is the Subversion way to move a working copy to a new branch. (See ) for an in-depth look at switching.

refsect1.title: Alternate names
refsect1.para: sw

refsect1.title: Changes
refsect1.para: Working copy

refsect1.title: Accesses Repository
refsect1.para: Yes

refsect1.title: Switches
refsect1.screen: --revision (-r) REV --non-recursive (-N) --quiet (-q) --username USER --password PASS --no-auth-cache --non-interactive

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: If you're currently inside the directory 'vendors' which was branched to 'vendors-with-fix' and you'd like to switch your working copy to that branch:
refsect1.screen: $ svn switch http://svn.red-bean.com/repos/branches/vendors-with-fix . U myproj/foo.txt U myproj/bar.txt U myproj/baz.c U myproj/qux.c Updated to revision 31.
refsect1.para: And to switch back, just provide the URL to the location in the repository from which you originally checked out your working copy:
refsect1.screen: $ svn switch http://svn.red-bean.com/repos/trunk/vendors . U myproj/foo.txt U myproj/bar.txt U myproj/baz.c U myproj/qux.c Updated to revision 31.

tip.para: You can just switch part of your working copy to a branch if you don't want to switch your entire working copy.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Updates your working copy.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: svn update brings changes from the repository into your working copy. If no revision given, it brings your working copy up-to-date with the HEAD revision. Otherwise, it synchronizes the working copy to the revision given by the --revision switch.
For each updated item a line will start with a character reporting the action taken. These characters have the following meaning:

listitem.para: Added
Deleted
Updated
Conflict
Merged

refsect1.para: A character in the first column signifies an update to the actual file, while updates to the file's properties are shown in the second column.

refsect1.title: Alternate names
refsect1.para: up

refsect1.title: Changes
refsect1.para: Working copy

refsect1.title: Accesses Repository
refsect1.para: Yes

refsect1.title: Switches
refsect1.screen: --revision (-r) REV --non-recursive (-N) --quiet (-q) --username USER --password PASS --no-auth-cache --non-interactive

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: Pick up repository changes that have happened since your last update:
refsect1.screen: $ svn update A newdir/toggle.c A newdir/disclose.c A newdir/launch.c D newdir/README Updated to revision 32.
refsect1.para: You can also update your working copy to an older revision (Subversion doesn't have the concept of sticky files like CVS does. See ):
refsect1.screen: svn update -r30 A newdir/README D newdir/toggle.c D newdir/disclose.c D newdir/launch.c U foo.c Updated to revision 30.

tip.para: If you want to examine an older revision of a single file, you may want to use svn cat.

sect1.para: svnadmin is the administrative tool for monitoring and repairing your Subversion repository. For detailed information, see

warning.para: Unlike svn, svnadmin (as well as other repository administration tools) operates on paths not URLs.

listitem.para: Follow copy history when examining a path.
Specify a template for the repository structure when creating a new repository.

The in-repository templates specify the layout of the repository itself (which lives in Berkeley DB files inside the db/ directory) like /trunk, /branches, etc. These templates can be used by an administrator or application to do an initial load of the repository (without invoking hooks). There is no default; the repository is built empty unless you tell it otherwise.
Dump a revision only as a diff against the previous revision, instead of the usual fulltext.
Specify a templete to use for the on-disk structure (i.e. conf/, hooks/, etc.) of the repository you want to create.
The on-disk templates describe the repository directory itself. Each of the templates have a name, and the default on-disk template contains:
default/
README
dav/
format
hooks/
post-commit.tmpl
post-revprop-change.tmpl
pre-commit.tmpl
pre-revprop-change.tmpl
start-commit.tmpl
locks/
db.lock

The typical usage for the on-disk structures is to predefine the hook scripts that will be created. For example, you could prepopulate the post-commit script with a commit mailer and backup script. Then, each time the administrator creates a new repository, she can refer to this new template which automagically includes all of the hooks.
Specify a particular revision to operate on.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Create a new, empty repository at REPOS_PATH.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Create a new, empty repository at the path provided. If the provided directory does not exist, it will be created for you.

refsect1.title: Switches
refsect1.screen: --on-disk-template arg --in-repos-template arg

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: Creating a new repository is just this easy:
refsect1.screen: $ svnadmin create /usr/local/svn/repos

refnamediv.refpurpose: Dump the contents of filesystem to stdout.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Dump the contents of filesystem to stdout in a 'dumpfile' portable format, sending feedback to stderr. Dump revisions LOWER rev through UPPER rev. If no revisions are given, dump all revision trees. If only LOWER is given, dump that one revision tree. See for a practical use.

refsect1.title: Switches
refsect1.screen: --revision (-r) --incremental

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: Dump your whole repository:
refsect1.screen: $ svnadmin dump /usr/local/svn/repos SVN-fs-dump-format-version: 1 Revision-number: 0 * Dumped revision 0. Prop-content-length: 56 Content-length: 56 ...
refsect1.para: Incrementally dump a single transaction from your repository:
refsect1.screen: $ svnadmin dump /usr/local/svn/repos -r 21 --incremental * Dumped revision 21. SVN-fs-dump-format-version: 1 Revision-number: 21 Prop-content-length: 101 Content-length: 101 ...

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: This subcommand is useful when you're trapped on a desert island with neither a net connection nor a copy of this book.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Read a dumpfile-formatted stream from STDIN.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Read a dumpfile-formatted stream from stdin, committing new revisions into the repository's filesystem. Send progress feedback to stdout.

refsect1.title: Example
refsect1.para: This shows the beginning of loading a repository from a backup file (made, of course, with svn dump):
refsect1.screen: $ svnadmin load /usr/local/svn/restored < repos-backup <<< Started new txn, based on original revision 1 * adding path : test ... done. * adding path : test/a ... done. ...

refnamediv.refpurpose: Print, one-per-line and youngest-to-eldest, the revisions in which PATH was modified.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para:
lscr
It's not immediately obvious, but lscr stands for LiSt Changed Revisions. That's what happens when you let programmers come up with names for commands.
prints, one-per-line and youngest-to-eldest, the revisions in which PATH was modified. Use the COPIES flag to allow this operation to cross copy history while searching for revisions. PATH must exist in the HEAD of the repository).

refsect1.title: Switches
refsect1.screen: --copies

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: List the revisions in which a path was modified:
refsect1.screen: $ svnadmin lscr /usr/local/svn/repos/ test-moved-file 34 33
refsect1.para: List the revisions in which a path was modified including changes that occured before it was moved/copied:
refsect1.screen: $ svnadmin lscr /usr/local/svn/repos/ test-moved-file --copies 34 33 15 14 ...

refnamediv.refpurpose: Print the names of all uncommitted transactions.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Print the names of all uncommitted transactions. See for information on how uncommitted transactions are created and what you should do with them.

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: List all outstanding transactions in a repository.
refsect1.screen: $ svnadmin lstxns /usr/local/svn/repos/ 1w 1x

refnamediv.refpurpose: Recovers any lost state in a repository.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Run this command if you get an error indicating that your repository needs to be recovered.

warning.para: Only run this when you are absolutely certain you're the only process accessing the repository—it requires exclusive access. See for a detailed explanation of repository recovery.

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: Recover a hung repository:
refsect1.screen: $ svnadmin recover /usr/local/svn/repos/ Acquiring exclusive lock on repository db. Recovery is running, please stand by... Recovery completed. The latest repos revision is 34.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Deletes transactions from a repository.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Deletes outstanding transactions from a repository. This is covered in detail in

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: Remove named transactions:
refsect1.screen: $ svnadmin rmtxns /usr/local/svn/repos/ 1w 1x
refsect1.para: Fortunately, the output of svn lstxns works great as the input for rmtxns:
refsect1.screen: $ svnadmin rmtxns /usr/local/svn/repos/ `svnadmin lstxns /usr/local/svn/repos/`
refsect1.para: Which will remove all uncommitted transactions from your repository.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Set the log-message on a revision.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Set the log-message on revision REVISION to the contents of FILE.

You might think that this sounds remarkably like the kind of thing that you can do by using svn propset --revprop to set the svn:log property on a revision. While it does, in fact, accomplish the same end result (changing the log message), setlog does not run any pre or post-commit hooks.

warning.para: Revision properties are not under version control, so this command will permanently overwrite the previous log message.

refsect1.title: Switches
refsect1.screen: --revision (-r) ARG

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: Set the log message for revision 19 to the contents of the file 'msg':
refsect1.screen: $ svnadmin setlog /usr/local/svn/repos/ -r 19 msg

sect1.para: svnlook is a command line utility for examining different aspects of a Subversion repository. It does not make any changes to the repository—it's just used for peeking.

svnlook is typically used by the repository hooks, but a repository administrator might find it useful for diagnostic purposes. Since svnlook can only be used on the machine that holds the repository, it takes paths as targets and not URLs.
If no revision or transaction is specified, svnlook defaults to the youngest (most recent) revision of the repository.

sect2.title: Switches
sect2.para: Switches in svnlook are global, just like in svn and svnadmin, however, most switches only apply to one subcommand since the functionality of svnlook is (intentionally) limited in scope.

listitem.para: Prevents svnlook from printing differences for deleted files. The default behavior when a file is deleted in a transaction/revision is to print the same differences that you would see if you had left the file but removed all the content.
Specify a particular revision number that you wish to examine.
Specify a particular transaction id that you wish to examine.
Show the filesystem node revision IDs for each path in the filesystem tree.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Prints the author.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Prints the author of a revision or transaction in the repository.

refsect1.title: Switches
refsect1.screen: --revision (-r) --transaction (-t)

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: svnlook author is handy, but not very exciting:
refsect1.screen: $ svnlook author -r 40 /usr/local/svn/repos sally

refnamediv.refpurpose: Print the paths that were changed.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Print the paths that were changed in a particular revision or transaction, as well as an svn update-style status letter in the first column: A for added, D for deleted, and U for updated (modified).

refsect1.title: Switches
refsect1.screen: --revision (-r) --transaction (-t)

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: This shows a list of all the changed files in revision 39 of a test repository:
refsect1.screen: $ svnlook changed -r 39 /usr/local/svn/repos A trunk/vendors/deli/ A trunk/vendors/deli/chips.txt A trunk/vendors/deli/sandwich.txt A trunk/vendors/deli/pickle.txt

refnamediv.refpurpose: Print the datestamp.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Print the datestamp of a revision or transaction in a repository.

refsect1.title: Switches
refsect1.screen: --revision (-r) --transaction (-t)

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: This shows the date of revision 40 of a test repository:
refsect1.screen: $ svnlook date -r 40 /tmp/repos/ 2003-02-22 17:44:49 -0600 (Sat, 22 Feb 2003)

refnamediv.refpurpose: Prints differences of changed files and properties.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Prints GNU-style differences of changed files and properties in a repository.

refsect1.title: Switches
refsect1.screen: --revision (-r) --transaction (-t) --no-diff-deleted

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: This shows a newly added (empty) file, a deleted file, and a copied file:
refsect1.screen:
$ svnlook diff -r 40 /usr/local/svn/repos/ Copied: egg.txt (from rev 39, trunk/vendors/deli/pickle.txt)
Added: trunk/vendors/deli/soda.txt ==============================================================================
Modified: trunk/vendors/deli/sandwich.txt ============================================================================== --- trunk/vendors/deli/sandwich.txt (original) +++ trunk/vendors/deli/sandwich.txt 2003-02-22 17:45:04.000000000 -0600 @@ -0,0 +1 @@ +Don't forget the mayo!
Deleted: trunk/vendors/deli/chips.txt ==============================================================================
Deleted: trunk/vendors/deli/pickle.txt ==============================================================================

refnamediv.refpurpose: Print the directories that were themselves changed.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Print the directories that were themselves changed (property edits) or whose file children were changed.

refsect1.title: Switches
refsect1.screen: --revision (-r) --transaction (-t)

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: This shows the directories that changed in revision 40 in our sample repository:
refsect1.screen: $ svnlook dirs-changed -r 40 /usr/local/svn/repos trunk/vendors/deli/

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Displays the help message for svnlook. This command, like it's brother svn, is also your friend, even though you never call it anymore and forgot to invite it to your last party.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Print the author, datestamp, log message size, and log message.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Print the author, datestamp, log message size, and log message.

refsect1.title: Switches
refsect1.screen: --revision (-r) --transaction (-t)

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: This shows the info output for revision 40 in our sample repository.
refsect1.screen: $ svnlook info -r 40 /usr/local/svn/repos sally 2003-02-22 17:44:49 -0600 (Sat, 22 Feb 2003) 15 Rearrange lunch.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Print the log message.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Print the log message.

refsect1.title: Switches
refsect1.screen: --revision (-r) --transaction (-t)

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: This shows the log output for revision 40 in our sample repository:
refsect1.screen: $ svnlook log /tmp/repos/ Rearrange lunch.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Print the tree

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Print the tree, optionally showing node revision ids.

refsect1.title: Switches
refsect1.screen: --revision (-r) --transaction (-t) --show-ids

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: This shows the tree output (with node-IDs) for revision 40 in our sample repository:
refsect1.screen: $ svnlook tree -r 40 /usr/local/svn/repos --show-ids / <0.0.2j> trunk/ <p.0.2j> vendors/ <q.0.2j> deli/ <1g.0.2j> egg.txt <1i.e.2j> soda.txt <1k.0.2j> sandwich.txt <1j.0.2j>

refnamediv.refpurpose: Print the youngest revision number.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Print the youngest revision number of a repository.

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: This shows the youngest revision of our sample repository:
refsect1.screen: $ svnlook youngest /tmp/repos/ 42
